metadata.name: Create Reusable Prompt Template for Recurring Task
metadata.description: Design, test, and document a reusable AI prompt template for tasks you perform repeatedly to ensure consistency and save time
prerequisites: Identified recurring task suitable for AI assistance
Access to AI tool (ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, etc.)
Storage location for template library (Notion, Docs, etc.)

outputs: Time saved on future instances of task (10-30 minutes per use)

steps.description: Identify a task you perform weekly or monthly that could benefit from AI assistance (e.g., prepare for meetings, write PRDs, review code, summarize research)
selection_criteria: Frequency: Performed weekly or monthly (not one-off)
AI-suitable: Involves writing, analysis, or synthesis

steps.description: Write a prompt for a specific instance of the task. Include all necessary context, desired format, tone, and constraints. Be detailed and specific
steps.output: Initial prompt that works for one specific instance
prompt_elements: Role/Persona (e.g., 'You are an expert product manager...')

steps.description: Run the prompt with your AI tool. Evaluate output quality against your expectations. Note what works well and what needs improvement
evaluation_criteria: Actionability: Can you use output with minimal editing?

steps.description: Transform specific prompt into template by replacing instance-specific details with placeholders (e.g., [STAKEHOLDER_NAME], [TOPIC], [TIMEFRAME]). Use [BRACKETS] or {CURLY_BRACES} for clarity
steps.output: Generalized prompt template with clear placeholders

parameterization_example.before: Prepare me for a meeting with Sarah about Q3 roadmap planning.
parameterization_example.after: Prepare me for a meeting with [STAKEHOLDER_NAME] about [TOPIC].

steps.description: Test template with 3-5 different scenarios (different parameters). Verify it produces quality output across varied inputs. Refine template if needed
Create template entry in your library with: name, description, template text, usage instructions, examples, and metadata (version, created date, last used)
steps.output: Fully documented template ready for reuse

documentation_structure.description: 1-2 sentence summary of what template does
documentation_structure.tips: Best practices for using this template

steps.description: Store template in your centralized library (Notion database, Google Doc, GitHub repo, etc.). Tag with category, department, frequency, and difficulty for easy discovery
organization_tags: Use case (Meeting prep, Content creation, Code review, etc.)

steps.description: If template is broadly applicable, share with team via Slack, email, or team meeting. Encourage feedback and contributions to improve template
steps.output: Template shared with team; feedback mechanism established
steps.sharing_message: Hey team! Created a new prompt template for [TASK]. Saves me ~20 minutes each time. Template: [LINK]. Try it out and let me know if you have suggestions!

quality_checklist: Template works across 3-5 diverse test scenarios
Documentation includes description, when to use, parameters, and example
Template produces usable output with <20% editing required
Template stored in accessible, organized library
Metadata includes version, created date, last updated
Template name follows consistent naming convention

template_structure_guide.example_filled:
You are an expert product manager at a SaaS company.

Task: Prepare me for a meeting with [STAKEHOLDER_NAME] about [TOPIC].

Context:
- Stakeholder role: [ROLE]
- Meeting goal: [GOAL]
- My objectives: [MY_OBJECTIVES]

Provide:
1. Key talking points (5-7 bullets)
2. Potential objections and counter-arguments
3. Questions to ask
4. Success criteria for the meeting

Format: Markdown with clear sections
Tone: Professional but conversational

meeting_preparation.name: Prepare-Stakeholder-Meeting
meeting_preparation.description: Prepare for upcoming stakeholder meeting with context and talking points
meeting_preparation.when_to_use: Weekly stakeholder syncs, quarterly business reviews, product demos
meeting_preparation.template: You are an expert product manager. Prepare me for a meeting with [STAKEHOLDER_NAME] about [TOPIC]. Context: Stakeholder role: [ROLE], Meeting goal: [GOAL], My objectives: [OBJECTIVES]. Provide: 1) Key talking points, 2) Potential objections, 3) Questions to ask, 4) Success criteria. Format: Markdown.

code_review.name: Review-Code-Security
code_review.description: Review code for security vulnerabilities and best practices
code_review.when_to_use: Before merging PRs, security audits, onboarding reviews
code_review.template:
You are a senior security engineer. Review this code for vulnerabilities: ```[LANGUAGE]
[CODE]
```. Analyze for: SQL injection, XSS, auth issues, data exposure, OWASP Top 10. For each issue: Severity, Description, Location, Remediation. Format: Markdown table.

research_summary.name: Summarize-Research-Paper
research_summary.description: Summarize academic paper with key findings and practical applications
research_summary.when_to_use: Literature reviews, staying current with research, team knowledge sharing
research_summary.template: You are a research analyst in [FIELD]. Summarize this paper: [TITLE/LINK]. Provide: 1) One-sentence summary, 2) Key findings (3-5 bullets), 3) Methodology overview, 4) Limitations, 5) Practical applications. Format: Structured markdown. Tone: Technical but accessible.

template_design: Start simple, add complexity only if needed
Provide default values for optional parameters in documentation
Include examples in template documentation (shows expected usage)
Test with edge cases before finalizing
library_organization: Group related templates (e.g., all meeting-prep templates together)
Archive rarely-used templates (don't delete - future reference)
Include 'last tested' date to flag potentially outdated templates
maintenance: Review templates quarterly (still relevant? still working?)
Refine when AI models improve (prompts may need adjustment)
Track which templates save most time (prioritize optimization)

common_mistakes: Template too specific (only works for one narrow scenario)
Poor placeholder naming ([X], [Y], [Z] instead of descriptive names)
No documentation (forget how to use template after 3 months)
Not testing with diverse inputs (fails on edge cases)
Creating too many templates (library becomes overwhelming)
No version control (lose track of what changed and why)
